text: United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
label: HH1

text: FORTUNATA CAPELLAN,
label: BODY

text: Claimant-Appellant,
label: BODY

text: JAMES B. PEAKE, M.D., Secretary of Veterans Affairs,
label: BODY

text: Respondent-Appellee.
label: BODY

text: Fortunata Capellan, of Lopez, Quezon, Philippines, pro se.
label: BODY

text: Douglas K. Mickle, Trial Attorney, Commercial Litigation Branch, Civil Division,
label: BODY

text: United States Department of Justice, of Washington, DC, for respondent-appellee.  With
label: BODY

text: him on the brief were Jeanne E. Davidson, Director, and Martin F. Hockey, Jr., Assistant
label: BODY

text: Director.  Of counsel on the brief were Michael J. Timinski, Deputy Assistant General
label: BODY

text: Counsel, and Jamie L. Mueller, Attorney, Office of the General Counsel, United States
label: BODY

text: Department of Veterans Affairs, of Washington, DC.
label: BODY

text: Appealed from:  United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims
label: BODY

text: Chief Judge William P. Greene, Jr.
label: BODY

text: United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
label: HH1

text: FORTUNATA CAPELLAN,
label: BODY

text: Claimant-Appellant,
label: BODY

text: JAMES B. PEAKE, M.D.,
label: BODY

text: Secretary of Veterans Affairs,
label: BODY

text: Respondent-Appellee.
label: BODY

text: Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims in Case No. 05-
label: BODY

text: 1990, Chief Judge William P. Greene, Jr.
label: BODY

text: DECIDED:  September 2, 2008
label: BODY

text: Before NEWMAN, MAYER, and SCHALL, Circuit Judges.
label: BODY

text: Opinion for the court filed by Circuit Judge NEWMAN.  Concurring opinion filed by
label: BODY

text: Circuit Judge SCHALL.
label: BODY

text: This appeal centers on the attempt of Fortunata Capellan to establish that her
label: BODY

text: husband, Santiago A. Capellan, was killed in the Battle of Bataan in 1942 while in the
label: BODY

text: Armed Forces of the Philippines in the service of the United States Armed Forces.  His
label: BODY

text: body was never recovered.  Mrs. Capellan’s claim is founded on 38 U.S.C. '107, which
label: BODY

text: provides certain veterans benefits to members of the Philippine military services who
label: BODY

text: were incorporated into the United States Armed Forces.  See 38 C.F.R. '3.40.
label: BODY

text: After the war Mrs. Capellan applied for veterans’ benefits based on her
label: BODY

text: husband’s service.  The application was granted and Mrs. Capellan received benefits
label: BODY

text: for several months in 1950 until they were terminated in August of that year.  This
label: BODY

text: appeal is from the most recent denial of her claim for dependency and indemnity
label: BODY

text: compensation, by decision of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims
label: BODY

text: (the “Veterans Court”).  The Veterans Court held that Mr. Capellan’s military service had
label: BODY

text: not been established by an official United States military document or verified by a
label: BODY

text: United States service department pursuant to 38 C.F.R. §3.203, and declined to
label: BODY

text: consider the new evidence from Philippine military authorities.1  In its ruling the
label: BODY

text: Veterans Court appears to have diverged from other decisions concerning verification of
label: BODY

text: Philippine military service when new information was provided after an earlier adverse
label: BODY

text: determination.  See, e.g., Padilla v. Nicholson, No. 05-2518, 2007 WL 412356, at *2
label: BODY

text: (Vet. App. Jan. 3, 2007) (requiring review of new information); Dela Cruz v. Nicholson,
label: BODY

text: No. 04-137, 2005 WL 3057877, at *3-*4 (Vet. App. Oct. 21, 2005) (requiring review of
label: BODY

text: new information).
label: BODY

text: At the threshold, the government challenges our jurisdiction of this appeal.
label: BODY

text: Jurisdiction
label: HH1

text: Pursuant to 38 U.S.C. '7292(a), as amended in 2002, this court has appellate
label: BODY

text: authority “with respect to the validity of a decision of the [Veterans Court] on a rule of
label: BODY

text: Capellan v. Nicholson, No. 05-1990, 2007 WL 561972 (Vet. App. Feb. 22,
label: BODY

text: law or of any statute or regulation . . . or any interpretation thereof . . . that was relied on
label: BODY

text: by the Court in making the decision.”  However, except to the extent that an appeal
label: BODY

text: presents a constitutional issue, this court “may not review (A) a challenge to a factual
label: BODY

text: determination, or (B) a challenge to a law or regulation as applied to the facts of a
label: BODY

text: particular case.”  38 U.S.C. '7292(d)(2).  The 2002 amendment to '7292(a) enlarged
label: BODY

text: our jurisdiction beyond issues of the validity or interpretation of a statute or regulation, to
label: BODY

text: include review of any legal principle and its interpretation.  See Morgan v. Principi, 327
label: BODY

text: F.3d 1357, 1361 (Fed. Cir. 2003) (“[T]he amendment enacted by Congress has the
label: BODY

text: effect of making the review of ‘a decision of the Court [of Appeals for Veterans Claims]
label: BODY

text: on a rule of law’ a separate jurisdictional basis, and textually independent of whether
label: BODY

text: that rule of law was ‘relied on’. . . .”); see also Wilson v. Principi, 391 F.3d 1203, 1209
label: BODY

text: (Fed. Cir. 2004) (“We have interpreted the revised statute as conferring on this court a
label: BODY

text: form of ‘case jurisdiction,’ as opposed to ‘issue jurisdiction.’”).
label: BODY

text: The Secretary of Veterans Affairs (herein “the VA”) argues that this court does
label: BODY

text: not have jurisdiction to consider any aspect of this appeal, stating that Mrs. Capellan is
label: BODY

text: simply seeking review of a factual determination concerning Mr. Capellan’s military
label: BODY

text: service.  Mrs. Capellan argues that the decision of the Veterans Court was based on an
label: BODY

text: incorrect interpretation of certain statutes and regulations.  The issues she raises
label: BODY

text: primarily concern 38 C.F.R. '3.203, a VA regulation that relates to evidence of military
label: BODY

text: service and that states the procedures to be followed by claimants and by the VA in
label: BODY

text: collaboration with the military services.  Mrs. Capellan argues that this regulation was
label: BODY

text: incorrectly interpreted in view of the VA’s statutory duty to assist, 38 U.S.C. '5103A,
label: BODY

text: and the benefit-of-the-doubt statute applicable to veterans’ claims, 38 U.S.C. §5107(b).
label: BODY

text: We conclude that the jurisdictional requirements of §7292 are met.  See Alpough
label: BODY

text: v. Nicholson, 490 F.3d 1352, 1358 (Fed. Cir. 2007) (accepting jurisdiction where the
label: BODY

text: Veterans Court relied on erroneous interpretations of 38 U.S.C. '101(3) and 38 C.F.R.
label: BODY

text: '3.53(b) in rejecting surviving spouse’s claim for benefits); Wilson, 391 F.3d at 1211
label: BODY

text: (accepting jurisdiction and remanding for reapplication of EAJA in light of statutory
label: BODY

text: change and intervening precedent).  We thus accept jurisdiction, and remand for
label: BODY

text: reapplication of the relevant statutory and regulatory provisions, consistent with this
label: BODY

text: opinion.
label: BODY

text: BACKGROUND
label: BODY

text: Before and during World War II the Commonwealth of the Philippines was a
label: BODY

text: territory of the United States.2  On July 26, 1941 President Roosevelt placed the military
label: BODY

text: forces of the Philippines in the service of the United States Armed Forces in the Far
label: BODY

text: East (USAFFE).  See Military Order, 6 Fed. Reg. 3825 (July 26, 1941).  The United
label: BODY

text: States duly provided that members of the Philippine military forces who fought the
label: BODY

text: Japanese invasion, or Philippine persons who fought as guerrillas during the Japanese
label: BODY

text: occupation, and their survivors, were eligible for certain benefits from the United States.
label: BODY

text: See 38 U.S.C. '107(a) (defining Philippine service qualifying for certain benefits,
label: BODY

text: including dependency and indemnity compensation for a surviving spouse pursuant to
label: BODY

text: chapter 13 of title 38); 38 C.F.R. ''3.40, 3.41 (specifying types of Philippine service
label: BODY

text: qualifying for dependency and indemnity compensation benefits).
label: BODY

text: Before the war, the Philippines had achieved a measure of self-
label: BODY

text: governance pursuant to the Philippine Independence Act of 1934, Pub. L. No. 73-127,
label: BODY

text: 48 Stat. 456.  The Philippines became independent on July 4, 1946.  See generally
label: BODY

text: Quiban v. Veterans Admin., 928 F.2d 1154, 1156-58 (D.C. Cir. 1991).
label: BODY

text: After the war Mrs. Capellan filed a claim for death pension and other benefits
label: BODY

text: based on her husband’s military service and his death at Bataan.  A United States Army
label: BODY

text: Report dated August 2, 1948 states that the Army confirmed that Santiago A. Capellan
label: BODY

text: served in the military service of the United States through the Philippine Commonwealth
label: BODY

text: Army, that his service began on December 23, 1941, and that he was killed in action on
label: BODY

text: February 28, 1942 during the battle for Bataan.  The Report states that Mr. Capellan
label: BODY

text: was a private in “B” Company, 1st Battalion, 1st Infantry Regiment, and that three
label: BODY

text: affidavits pertaining to his military service were attached.  On August 17, 1950 the Army
label: BODY

text: issued another Report, stating that Mr. Capellan “has no recognized guerrilla service
label: BODY

text: nor was he a member of the Commonwealth Army in the service of the Armed Forces of
label: BODY

text: the United States.”  The 1950 Report does not explain the change from the 1948
label: BODY

text: Report, although it refers to a separate “loyalty report” on Mr. Capellan’s father which is
label: BODY

text: not included in the record.  Mrs. Capellan briefly received benefits from the VA but they
label: BODY

text: were terminated in 1950.
label: BODY

text: The activity relevant to this appeal is focused on documentation from the
label: BODY

text: Philippine military authorities that Mrs. Capellan received in 1997 with respect to her
label: BODY

text: husband’s service and death at Bataan.  A document dated December 9, 1997, signed
label: BODY

text: by Records Officer Romeo L. Soriben and Captain Narciso S. Erna, Assistant Adjutant
label: BODY

text: General of the Armed Forces of the Philippines, certified that Private Santiago Capellan
label: BODY

text: served in the “B Co 1st Bn 1st Regt,” and described his service as:
label: BODY

text: Beleaguered status fr 19 Dec 41 to 28 Fed 42; Died at Bagac, Bataan
label: BODY

text: Phils on 28 Fed 42; Termination of casualty status on 23 Oct 44 (RPD dtd
label: BODY

text: Admin. Rec. at 15.  Mrs. Capellan also received a certification of the records of the
label: BODY

text: Armed Forces of the Philippines dated December 3, 1997 and signed by Captain
label: BODY

text: Narciso Erna, which recorded payments made in arrears for Mr. Capellan’s service
label: BODY

text: while a member of the Commonwealth Army of the Philippines in the
label: BODY

text: service of the USAFFE/GRLA.
label: BODY

text: Admin. Rec. at 16.  These documents were submitted in January 1998 to the VA
label: BODY

text: Regional Office in Manila.  In October 1999 the Regional Office wrote Mrs. Capellan
label: BODY

text: that it was unable to locate the relevant claims files and requested additional
label: BODY

text: information.  The Regional Office letter stated:
label: BODY

text: So that proper adjudicative action may be taken on your claim, you must
label: BODY

text: furnish the following:
label: BODY

text: VA Form 21-534.  Please fill out every blank which applies to you.
label: BODY

text: VA Form 21-4138.  Please explain why your benefits were
label: BODY

text: terminated in July 1950.
label: BODY

text: Copies of Notices of Award and Disallowance to include all
label: BODY

text: available previous VA correspondence.
label: BODY

text: A copy of the veteran’s death certificate.
label: BODY

text: A copy of your marriage certificate.
label: BODY

text: Admin. Rec. at 24.  Mrs. Capellan responded in December 1999, providing both
label: BODY

text: requested VA forms and stating that she had not received a death certificate because
label: BODY

text: her husband’s “body was unrecovered and no document was issued to us by proper
label: BODY

text: authorities.  I hope that this military service record will serve as his death certificate.”
label: BODY

text: She included a copy of her marriage certificate, and explained that her copies of the
label: BODY

text: Notices of Awards and Disallowances were misplaced or lost and could not be provided.
label: BODY

text: She explained that Mr. Capellan’s father had received a letter from the VA in July 1950
label: BODY

text: asking for Mr. Capellan’s military service record but that “[w]e were not able to submit
label: BODY

text: the document needed because of improper guidance,” and referred to a February 1951
label: BODY

text: letter from the VA stating that her benefits were terminated “for the reason that my
label: BODY

text: husband has no recognized guerilla service.”
label: BODY

text: The Regional Office requested a search for Mr. Capellan’s military records from
label: BODY

text: the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC) in Missouri.  The NPRC is part of the
label: BODY

text: United States National Archives and Records Administration, and receives and stores
label: BODY

text: records of various types concerning persons who served in the Armed Forces.  The
label: BODY

text: NPRC provided the Regional Office with the 1948 U.S. Army report, which stated that
label: BODY

text: Mr. Capellan had served with the Philippine Commonwealth Army in the service of the
label: BODY

text: United States Armed Forces from December 23, 1941 through February 28, 1942 when
label: BODY

text: he was killed in action.  The Regional Office then wrote the NPRC that it had “reason to
label: BODY

text: believe that there may have been a subsequent (1950) re-certification that revoked the
label: BODY

text: 1948 report.”  The NPRC then provided the 1950 Army Report, the NPRC stating that
label: BODY

text: “the determination of that date (8/17/50) stands.”  The record provided on this appeal
label: BODY

text: does not reflect that the VA provided the Philippine military records, or any of Mrs.
label: BODY

text: Capellan’s other evidence, to the NPRC for verification of service.
label: BODY

text: The Regional Office then denied Mrs. Capellan’s claim, stating that under 38
label: BODY

text: C.F.R. '3.203 decisions concerning verification of military service are the responsibility
label: BODY

text: of the NPRC and “are binding on the VA which has no authority to change or amend the
label: BODY

text: findings.”  Although the Regional Office decision listed the evidence provided by Mrs.
label: BODY

text: Capellan, including the newly provided 1997 documents from the Philippine military
label: BODY

text: officials and other post-1950 materials, the record shows no evaluation of this evidence
label: BODY

text: by the NPRC, the Regional Office, or any United States military authority.  The Regional
label: BODY

text: Office decision did not state that any of Mrs. Capellan’s post-1950 evidence had been
label: BODY

text: provided to the NPRC or any other authority for review.  The denial informed Mrs.
label: BODY

text: Capellan of her right to appeal, which would commence by filing a Notice of
label: BODY

text: Disagreement with the Regional Office.
label: BODY

text: Mrs. Capellan submitted a Notice of Disagreement, attaching some previously
label: BODY

text: submitted documentation from various Philippine authorities, including a document
label: BODY

text: dated March 5, 2002 from the Philippine Veterans Affairs Office stating that it certified
label: BODY

text: that Santiago Capellan “is a veteran of World War II/Philippine Revolution who served
label: BODY

text: with 1st Reg. Div. PA with the grade/rank Pvt,” that his service was in the USAFFE, and
label: BODY

text: that an Old Age Pension for his widow Fortunata Capellan based on his service was
label: BODY

text: approved on June 20, 1991.  Mrs. Capellan also refiled an October 25, 1955 affidavit of
label: BODY

text: Major Jose M. Javier, the commanding officer of the “B” Company, 1st Battalion, 1st
label: BODY

text: Infantry Regiment Division, which included the following:
label: BODY

text: 5.  That I know officially and personally the late veteran,
label: BODY

text: SANTIAGO CAPELLAN, a reservist who reported to active duty in the
label: BODY

text: Philippine Army and was inducted into the USAFFE on or about 18
label: BODY

text: December 1941, at Camp Murphy, by an American Officer, and was
label: BODY

text: assigned to my unit (“B” Co, 1st Bn, 1st Reg Div) as filler when my unit
label: BODY

text: suffered casualties after the fierce fighting against the enemy at Mauban,
label: BODY

text: Quezon; that said veteran, Santiago Capellan, was inducted into the
label: BODY

text: USAFFE as Private;
label: BODY

text: 6.  That the late Pvt. Santiago Capellan had rendered continuous
label: BODY

text: service and had seen actions in Bataan where he was killed in action
label: BODY

text: during the enemy bombing of our line of resistance at Bagac, Bataan, on
label: BODY

text: or about 15 February 1942, and died instantly;
label: BODY

text: Admin. Rec. at 77.
label: BODY

text: Other evidence submitted in 2002 included a Philippine Veterans Affairs Office
label: BODY

text: list of veterans including Mr. Capellan who were entitled to shares of the Philippine
label: BODY

text: Veterans Bank, and a stock certificate from the Philippine Veterans Bank showing Mrs.
label: BODY

text: Capellan’s status as the widow and heir of Santiago Capellan.  Also resubmitted was an
label: BODY

text: affidavit, dated August 18, 1946, of both the mayor and the chief of police of the city of
label: BODY

text: Lopez, where Mr. Capellan had lived, stating that they each personally knew
label: BODY

text: Santiago Capellan, a Reservist Private who left this municipality of Lopez,
label: BODY

text: province of Tayabas, for active Military Service on December 19, 1941,
label: BODY

text: and from that time to the present time [August 18, 1946], said Reservist,
label: BODY

text: Santiago Capellan had not returned to his family.
label: BODY

text: Admin. Rec. at 78.  Also resubmitted was the March 20, 1969 affidavit of two military
label: BODY

text: comrades of Mr. Capellan, Vicente Pilarca and Inocencio Anacion, who stated that they
label: BODY

text: served with Santiago Capellan in the Philippine Army at Bataan and saw him hit by
label: BODY

text: enemy bullets and killed.  The affidavit states:
label: BODY

text: That we both personally know one, SANTIAGO CAPELLAN, a boyhood
label: BODY

text: friend and townmate whom we met in Bataan somewhere in Abucay, and
label: BODY

text: who told us, he was in uniform, that he was inducted into the USAFFE at
label: BODY

text: Lucena, Quezon (Tayabas) as private in "B" Co., 1st Inf. under Lt.
label: BODY

text: Cuaresma;
label: BODY

text: That in the main Japanese Offensive at Balanga, we met the said veteran
label: BODY

text: and in the haste of retreat, we chanced to be together and that while
label: BODY

text: together, he was hit by enemy bullets causing his death, his body having
label: BODY

text: been unrecovered;
label: BODY

text: That the late Private SANTIAGO CAPELLAN died in action on or about
label: BODY

text: the month of February, the date we could not recall at present, in the year
label: BODY

text: That we know the above facts because the said veteran was with us
label: BODY

text: during the critical days of the battle at Bataan and we personally saw him
label: BODY

text: hit and died of enemy bullets;
label: BODY

text: Admin. Rec. at 100.
label: BODY

text: The Regional Office held a hearing in Manila on September 10, 2002.  In addition
label: BODY

text: to the documentary records, Mrs. Capellan and two family members testified that her
label: BODY

text: husband was killed in action while serving in the USAFFE.  They provided a photograph
label: BODY

text: of Mr. Capellan in military uniform, and a group photo with his battalion.  The Regional
label: BODY

text: Office then denied the claim, stating that the 1950 Army Report was dispositive and that
label: BODY

text: the entirety of the evidence provided by Mrs. Capellan “cannot be accepted as proof of
label: BODY

text: military service of your deceased husband in absence of substantiating evidence in the
label: BODY

text: records of the Army.”  The Regional Office did not discuss any of the evidence, and
label: BODY

text: sought no substantiation from the United States or Philippine military authorities.
label: BODY

text: Mrs. Capellan appealed to the Board of Veterans Appeals, which held that the
label: BODY

text: duties to notify and to assist should be applied, and remanded “to obtain additional
label: BODY

text: development and full compliance with the VA’s due process requirements.”  On March
label: BODY

text: 5, 2004 the VA Appeals Management Center wrote to Mrs. Capellan and asked her to
label: BODY

text: “Please provide us with any evidence or information you may have pertaining to your
label: BODY

text: appeal.  Provide medical evidence (that you have not already submitted) that will show
label: BODY

text: that the deceased had valid military service.”  The letter stated that the VA was
label: BODY

text: responsible for retrieving “[r]elevant records from any Federal agency,” and would make
label: BODY

text: reasonable efforts to get “[r]elevant records not held by a Federal agency.”  Mrs.
label: BODY

text: Capellan was instructed to “give us enough information about your records so that we
label: BODY

text: can request them from the person or agency that has them.”  The letter also stated:  “It’s
label: BODY

text: your responsibility to make sure that we receive all requested records that aren’t in the
label: BODY

text: possession of a Federal department or agency.”
label: BODY

text: On April 24, 2004 Mrs. Capellan replied to the Appeals Management Center and
label: BODY

text: referred to the evidence in her file, pointing to the affidavits from persons who knew Mr.
label: BODY

text: Capellan and witnessed his military service and saw his death in action at Bataan.  She
label: BODY

text: stated that his body was never recovered, and that there was thus no medical evidence
label: BODY

text: of his death.  The Appeals Management Center then denied her claim, stating that “[t]he
label: BODY

text: “evidence clearly indicates that Santiago A. Capellan has no recognized guerrilla
label: BODY

text: service, nor was he a member of the Commonwealth Army of the Philippines in the
label: BODY

text: service of the Armed Forces of the United States.”  The decision did not discuss any of
label: BODY

text: Mrs. Capellan’s evidence, and it appears that the Center relied solely on the 1950 U.S.
label: BODY

text: Army Report in reaching its conclusion, stating that “substantial evidence” to refute this
label: BODY

text: conclusion had not been submitted.  The Center did not say how or if the Center had
label: BODY

text: assisted, although it stated that a March 2003 letter met the VA’s duty to notify the
label: BODY

text: claimant of her rights.
label: BODY

text: Mrs. Capellan appealed to the Board, and summarized the material she had
label: BODY

text: submitted as follows:
label: BODY

text: It is not only the Affidavits of Lucia V. Almacha and Natividad C.
label: BODY

text: Escobido [relatives] that were submitted.  But many other documents that
label: BODY

text: substantiated my claim and considered as New and Material Evidences.
label: BODY

text: Some of the material evidences are as follows:
label: BODY

text: Affidavit of Mr. Vicente Pilarca.
label: BODY

text: An eyewitness that my husband in Uniform as a USAFFE
label: BODY

text: participated in the Battle of Bataan.
label: BODY

text: Inocencio Anacion
label: BODY

text: Comrades-in-arms and eyewitness that my husband in
label: BODY

text: uniform of the USAFFE was killed in action in Bataan.
label: BODY

text: Masterlists of the Shareholders of Stock Certificate of the Philippine
label: BODY

text: Veterans Bank, owned by the World War II Veterans.
label: BODY

text: Certification of Military Service from the Non-Current Branch Office
label: BODY

text: Division, Gen. Headquarters, AFP, Camp Gen. Emilio Aguinaldo,
label: BODY

text: Quezon City, Philippines.
label: BODY

text: Certification of Salaries and Allowances received during the World
label: BODY

text: War II, as a Backpay from the Gen. Headquarters, Camp Gen.
label: BODY

text: Emilio Aguinaldo, Quezon City, Philippines.
label: BODY

text: Certification from the Phil. Veterans Affairs Office of my husband's
label: BODY

text: Military Service during World War II.
label: BODY

text: Affidavit of Mr. Jose M. Javier, during their Defense of Bataan,
label: BODY

text: together with my husband.
label: BODY

text: Picture of my husband during their USAFFE training in Port Area,
label: BODY

text: Manila, Philippines, in uniform.  His picture is with a check.
label: BODY

text: Admin. Rec. at 159-160.
label: BODY

text: On March 25, 2005 the Board denied Mrs. Capellan's claim, stating that none of
label: BODY

text: the evidence she submitted could be considered because none of it was a “document
label: BODY

text: issued by a U.S. Service Department,” quoting 38 C.F.R. '3.203.  The Board cited Duro
label: BODY

text: v. Derwinski, 2 Vet. App. 530 (1992), which held that the “VA is prohibited from finding,
label: BODY

text: on any basis other than a service department document, which VA believes to be
label: BODY

text: authentic and accurate, or service department verification, that a particular individual
label: BODY

text: served in the U.S. Armed Forces.”  Id. at 532.  She was informed of the right to appeal
label: BODY

text: to the Veterans Court.
label: BODY

text: With her appeal to the Veterans Court, Mrs. Capellan again pointed to the
label: BODY

text: evidence from the Philippine military authorities and others attesting to her husband's
label: BODY

text: military service and to his death at Bataan.  She stated that a thorough investigation by
label: BODY

text: the Philippine Judge Advocate General’s Office in 1947 had determined that Mr.
label: BODY

text: Capellan had served and was killed in action, and provided the additional information
label: BODY

text: that had been before the Board.  She stated that it was known that Philippine military
label: BODY

text: personnel were not fully recorded in the NPRC archives, citing specific examples, and
label: BODY

text: that these records were especially deficient as to Philippine personnel killed in the war.
label: BODY

text: In the Veterans Court, the VA acknowledged Mrs. Capellan’s evidence, including
label: BODY

text: the certification of her husband’s military status from the Philippine Armed Forces, but
label: BODY

text: argued that there was a “plausible basis” for the Board’s decision in light of the
label: BODY

text: evidentiary requirements of 38 C.F.R. §3.203.  The Veterans Court ruled that the VA is
label: BODY

text: bound by the United States Army’s 1950 report, and that none of the subsequent
label: BODY

text: evidence could be considered because it was not issued by a United States military
label: BODY

text: service department.  The Veterans Court cited Duro, 2 Vet. App. at 532, and Soria v.
label: BODY

text: Brown, 118 F.3d 747, 749 (Fed. Cir. 1997), where the Federal Circuit observed that
label: BODY

text: “Philippine veterans are not eligible for veterans’ benefits unless a United States service
label: BODY

text: department documents or certifies their service.”  Subsequent cases have recognized
label: BODY

text: that the Soria decision preceded the enactment in 2000 of the statutory duty to assist.
label: BODY

text: See Palor v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 325, 330-31 (2007) (discussing effect of Veterans
label: BODY

text: Claims Assistance Act on Soria decision).
label: BODY

text: DISCUSSION
label: BODY

text: The record does not show any request by any VA authority for service
label: BODY

text: department review of any of the documents provided by Mrs. Capellan as she
label: BODY

text: proceeded, over the years, in the Regional Office and the Board of Veterans Appeals
label: BODY

text: and the Veterans Court — although 38 C.F.R. '3.203(c) states that the VA “shall
label: BODY

text: request verification of service from the service department”:
label: BODY

text: 38 C.F.R. '3.203  Service records as evidence of service and character of
label: BODY

text: discharge.
label: BODY

text: (a) Evidence submitted by a claimant.  For the purpose of establishing
label: BODY

text: entitlement to pension, compensation, dependency and indemnity
label: BODY

text: compensation or burial benefits the Department of Veterans Affairs may
label: BODY

text: accept evidence of service submitted by the claimant (or sent directly to
label: BODY

text: the Department of Veterans Affairs by the service department), such as a
label: BODY

text: DD Form 214, Certificate of Release or Discharge from Active Duty, or
label: BODY

text: original Certificate of Discharge, without verification from the appropriate
label: BODY

text: service department if the evidence meets the following conditions:
label: BODY

text: (1) The evidence is a document issued by the service
label: BODY

text: department. . . .
label: BODY

text: (c) Verification from the service department.  When the claimant does
label: BODY

text: not submit evidence of service or the evidence submitted does not meet
label: BODY

text: the requirements of paragraph (a) of this section (and paragraph (b) of this
label: BODY

text: section in pension claims), the Department of Veterans Affairs shall
label: BODY

text: request verification of service from the service department. . . .
label: BODY

text: Section 3.203 is a general evidentiary rule; it contains no special provisions concerning
label: BODY

text: Philippine military service as recognized under 38 U.S.C. §107(a).  Thus section
label: BODY

text: 3.203(c) requires verification of service from the service department whenever a
label: BODY

text: claimant lacks the kind of official evidence specified in section 3.203(a).  The reports of
label: BODY

text: all of the tribunals in the records provided to us show that they treated the 1950 Army
label: BODY

text: Report as dispositive because it was the last review by the Army.  While this 1950 Army
label: BODY

text: Report was located by the NPRC in response to a specific VA search request in 2001,
label: BODY

text: after the first VA search request had turned up only the 1948 Army Report, the record
label: BODY

text: does not show that the VA ever provided any of Mrs. Capellan’s post-1950 evidence to
label: BODY

text: the Army or to the NPRC.  Mrs. Capellan argues that this rejection of her claim without
label: BODY

text: review of all the evidence did not comport with the VA’s duty to assist her, and the
label: BODY

text: obligation to afford her claim the benefit of the doubt based on all the evidence.  The
label: BODY

text: provision by the NPRC of the Reports in its archives does not constitute review of all the
label: BODY

text: evidence related to military service.
label: BODY

text: The “duty to assist,” 38 U.S.C. '5103A; 38 C.F.R. §3.159, although mentioned by
label: BODY

text: the VA, does not appear to have been invoked to provide agency assistance in
label: BODY

text: procuring the requisite “verification of service from the service department.”  Similarly,
label: BODY

text: the “benefit of the doubt” statute, 38 U.S.C. §5107(b), was ruled inapplicable by the
label: BODY

text: Veterans Court because the court stated that the evidence was not in equipoise.  The
label: BODY

text: Veterans Court, like the Board, interpreted 38 C.F.R. §3.203(c) to negate consideration
label: BODY

text: of the post-1950 evidence submitted by the claimant.  This interpretation of section
label: BODY

text: 3.203(c), relied on by the Veterans Court and the VA, is incorrect in light of the legal
label: BODY

text: requirements of assistance to claimants.
label: BODY

text: The “duty to assist” statute and regulations apply to all evidence needed to
label: BODY

text: substantiate a claim.  The VA’s obligation includes assisting the claimant in developing
label: BODY

text: her claim by making “as many requests as are necessary to obtain relevant records
label: BODY

text: from a Federal department or agency.”  38 C.F.R. §3.159(c)(2).  In this case, it is not
label: BODY

text: explained how this duty was met, for, according to the record, service department
label: BODY

text: consideration was not requested for any evidence that Mrs. Capellan provided after
label: BODY

text: 1950.  The Veterans Court has interpreted section 3.203(c) consonant with the current
label: BODY

text: duty to assist, stating that “when a claimant submits evidence establishing that the
label: BODY

text: service department’s certification was based upon erroneous information, a second
label: BODY

text: certification may be required.”  Laruan v. West, 11 Vet. App. 80, 82 (1998) (en banc),
label: BODY

text: overruled on other grounds by D’Amico v. West, 209 F.3d 1322, 1327 (Fed. Cir. 2000).
label: BODY

text: Similarly, in Padilla v. Nicholson, No. 05-2518, 2007 WL 412356, at *2 (Vet. App. Jan. 3,
label: BODY

text: 2007) the Veterans Court held that the Board erred in relying on an earlier NPRC record
label: BODY

text: rather than submitting the new evidence concerning the claimed military service.  The
label: BODY

text: court stated: “When new identifying information is provided by the appellant, the
label: BODY

text: Secretary ‘shall request verification of service from the service department.’” Id. (quoting
label: BODY

text: 38 C.F.R. §3.203(c)).  See also Dela Cruz v. Nicholson, No. 04-137, 2005 WL 3057877,
label: BODY

text: at *3 (Vet. App. Oct. 21, 2005) (applying duty to assist where it was unclear whether the
label: BODY

text: proper form had been used to obtain an affidavit from the Philippine Army in connection
label: BODY

text: with a request for verification of service).  In Sarmiento v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 80 (1994),
label: BODY

text: overruled on other grounds by D’Amico, 209 F.3d at 1227, the Veterans Court stated
label: BODY

text: that “there is no stated limit on the number of times that the Secretary ‘shall’ request
label: BODY

text: service department verification when one claiming entitlement fails to submit qualifying
label: BODY

text: evidence of service.”  Id. at 85.  We conclude that the correct interpretation of the
label: BODY

text: governing statutes and regulations requires that a claimant’s new evidence be
label: BODY

text: submitted and considered in connection with a request for “verification of service from
label: BODY

text: the service department” pursuant to 38 C.F.R. §3.203(c).
label: BODY

text: The “benefit of the doubt” statute, 38 U.S.C. §5107(b), and the analogous
label: BODY

text: “reasonable doubt” regulation, 38 C.F.R. §3.102, apply to all material issues relating to
label: BODY

text: a claim, including verification of military service.  See Kelly v. Nicholson, 463 F.3d 1349,
label: BODY

text: 1354 (Fed. Cir. 2006) (stating that 38 U.S.C. §5107(b) “applies not only to decisions
label: BODY

text: relating to the overall merits of a claim, but by its plain language it applies to all
label: BODY

text: decisions determining any material issue relating to a claim”).  The VA argues that these
label: BODY

text: provisions are outside our appellate jurisdiction because they relate to the weighing of
label: BODY

text: evidence, which is excluded from our review by 38 U.S.C. §7292(d)(2).  We agree that
label: BODY

text: the weighing of evidence is not within our appellate authority.  However, when statute
label: BODY

text: and regulation require that the veterans’ tribunals weigh the evidence, our authority
label: BODY

text: includes assuring that the evidence is weighed under the appropriate statutes and
label: BODY

text: regulations.  See Buchanan v. Nicholson, 451 F.3d 1331, 1335 (Fed. Cir. 2006)
label: BODY

text: (Federal Circuit has jurisdiction to review interpretation of the benefit of the doubt rule
label: BODY

text: and other legal provisions).  Both the statute and the regulation explicitly require the
label: BODY

text: consideration of all evidence submitted by the claimant.  See 38 U.S.C. §5107(b) (“The
label: BODY

text: Secretary shall consider all information and lay and medical evidence of record in a
label: BODY

text: case before the Secretary with respect to benefits under laws administered by the
label: BODY

text: Secretary.”); 38 C.F.R. §3.102 (“When, after careful consideration of all procurable and
label: BODY

text: assembled data, a reasonable doubt exists regarding service origin, the degree of
label: BODY

text: disability, or any other point, such doubt will be resolved in favor of the claimant.”).  The
label: BODY

text: reasonable doubt regulation by its terms applies “even in the absence of official records,
label: BODY

text: particularly if the basic incident allegedly arose under combat, or similarly strenuous
label: BODY

text: conditions, and is consistent with the probable results of such known hardships.”  38
label: BODY

text: C.F.R. §3.102.  In accordance with 38 C.F.R. §3.203(c), the agency is required to
label: BODY

text: ensure consideration of “all procurable and assembled data,” including lay evidence, in
label: BODY

text: connection with a request for “verification of service from the service department.”
label: BODY

text: 38 C.F.R. §3.203 requires that Mr. Capellan’s military service be determined
label: BODY

text: based on all relevant evidence, with due application of the duty to assist, 38 U.S.C.
label: BODY

text: §5103A; 38 C.F.R. §3.159, and the statutory and regulatory requirements to consider
label: BODY

text: “all information and lay . . . evidence of record,” 38 U.S.C. §5107(b); see also 38 C.F.R.
label: BODY

text: §3.102.  The VA erred in denying Mrs. Capellan’s claim based on the archival 1950
label: BODY

text: Army Report, while obtaining no review of the subsequent evidence by the service
label: BODY

text: department.  We vacate the decision of the Veterans Court, and remand for
label: BODY

text: determination, on the entirety of the evidence, of Mr. Capellan’s military service.
label: BODY

text: VACATED AND REMANDED
label: BODY

text: United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
label: HH1

text: FORTUNATA CAPELLAN,
label: BODY

text: Claimant-Appellant,
label: BODY

text: JAMES B. PEAKE, M.D.,
label: BODY

text: Secretary of Veterans Affairs,
label: BODY

text: Respondent-Appellee.
label: BODY

text: Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims in Case No. 05-
label: BODY

text: 1990, Chief Judge William P. Greene, Jr.
label: BODY

text: SCHALL, Circuit Judge, concurring.
label: BODY

text: The court holds that the Department of Veterans Affairs (“VA”) failed to comply
label: BODY

text: with the duty to assist because it did not furnish the Department of the Army with the
label: BODY

text: material provided by Mrs. Capellan in support of her claim and did not request from the
label: BODY

text: service department, pursuant to 38 C.F.R. § 3.203(c), verification of the military service
label: BODY

text: of her husband, Santiago Capellan.  Based upon its holding, the court remands the
label: BODY

text: case to the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims (“Veterans Court”) for further
label: BODY

text: proceedings.  In that regard, the final paragraph of the opinion reads as follows:
label: BODY

text: 38 C.F.R. §3.203 requires that Mr. Capellan’s military service be
label: BODY

text: determined based on all relevant evidence, with due application of the
label: BODY

text: duty to assist, 38 U.S.C. §5103A; 38 C.F.R. §3.159, and the statutory and
label: BODY

text: regulatory requirements to consider “all information and lay . . . evidence
label: BODY

text: of record,” 38 U.S.C. §5107(b); see also 38 C.F.R. 3.102.  The VA erred in
label: BODY

text: denying Mrs. Capellan’s claim based on the archival 1950 Army Report,
label: BODY

text: while obtaining no review of the subsequent evidence by the service
label: BODY

text: department.  We vacate the decision of the Veterans Court, and remand
label: BODY

text: for determination, on the entirety of the evidence, of Mr. Capellan’s military
label: BODY

text: service.
label: BODY

text: I agree that the VA failed to comply with the duty to assist.  I also agree that a
label: BODY

text: remand is necessary.  I write separately, however, to express my view that the only
label: BODY

text: appropriate remand in this case is a remand in which the Veterans Court directs the VA
label: BODY

text: to request verification, pursuant to 38 C.F.R. § 3.203(c), of Santiago Capellan’s military
label: BODY

text: service and in which the Veterans Court directs the VA to provide the service
label: BODY

text: department with all the material submitted by Mrs. Capellan in support of her claim.  Any
label: BODY

text: other remand activity by the Veterans Court beyond this would, in my view, be contrary
label: BODY

text: to this court’s decision in Soria v. Brown, 118 F.3d 747 (Fed. Cir. 1997).  After the
label: BODY

text: service department acts on the request for verification, the VA will be in a position to
label: BODY

text: rule on Mrs. Capellan’s claim.
